unnormalised: Okay, so you know how everyone’s always talking about government jobs and all the "sarkari" stuff, right? Well, I thought I'd break down some of the common designations and roles you might hear about, especially since my cousin, Priya, just cracked the UPSC! So exciting!
normalised: Okay, so you know how everyone is always talking about government jobs and all the "sarkari" stuff, right? Well, I thought I would break down some of the common designations and roles you might hear about, especially since my cousin, Priya, just cracked the U-P-S-C! So exciting!

unnormalised: First up, you’ve got the classic "DM," or District Magistrate. Basically, they're the boss of a district. Think of them as the CEO of a specific geographical area. They're responsible for maintaining law and order, collecting revenue, and overseeing the implementation of government schemes. Priya's aiming for that post eventually! You’ll also hear people say “Collector,” same thing, just different terms used in different states. My uncle keeps calling her "Collector Madam" already, haha!
normalised: First up, you have got the classic "D-M," or District Magistrate. Basically, they are the boss of a district. Think of them as the C-E-O of a specific geographical area. They are responsible for maintaining law and order, collecting revenue, and overseeing the implementation of government schemes. Priya is aiming for that post eventually! You will also hear people say “Collector,” same thing, just different terms used in different states. My uncle keeps calling her "Collector Madam" already, haha!

unnormalised: Then there’s the "SDM," or Sub-Divisional Magistrate. They’re like the DM’s right-hand person, handling a smaller chunk of the district. Consider them junior DMs-in-training, gaining experience. They handle similar responsibilities but on a smaller scale. Sometimes they get called “Tehsildar” too. It depends on the specific role and state laws.
normalised: Then there is the "S-D-M," or Sub-Divisional Magistrate. They are like the D-M's right-hand person, handling a smaller chunk of the district. Consider them junior D-Ms-in-training, gaining experience. They handle similar responsibilities but on a smaller scale. Sometimes they get called “Tehsildar” too. It depends on the specific role and state laws.

unnormalised: You'll often come across "BDOs," or Block Development Officers. These guys are responsible for rural development at the block level – a cluster of villages. They work on things like implementing agricultural programs, building infrastructure, and promoting education.
normalised: You will often come across "B-D-Os," or Block Development Officers. These guys are responsible for rural development at the block level – a cluster of villages. They work on things like implementing agricultural programs, building infrastructure, and promoting education.

unnormalised: "IAS officers" are a pretty big deal. These are the folks who’ve passed the super-tough UPSC exam and get assigned to various roles at the state and central government levels. They could become DMs, secretaries, or head various departments. It’s a really prestigious posting!
normalised: "I-A-S officers" are a pretty big deal. These are the folks who have passed the super-tough U-P-S-C exam and get assigned to various roles at the state and central government levels. They could become D-Ms, secretaries, or head various departments. It is a really prestigious posting!

unnormalised: "IPS officers" are the police force's equivalent of IAS officers. They're responsible for maintaining law and order and preventing crime. You’ll find them as SPs (Superintendents of Police) at the district level, or heading up different divisions within the police force.
normalised: "I-P-S officers" are the police force's equivalent of I-A-S officers. They are responsible for maintaining law and order and preventing crime. You will find them as S-Ps (Superintendents of Police) at the district level, or heading up different divisions within the police force.

unnormalised: Then you’ve got your "Chief Secretary" at the state level. They are the top bureaucrat in the state government, advising the Chief Minister on all policy matters. These guys are seasoned veterans.
normalised: Then you have got your "Chief Secretary" at the state level. They are the top bureaucrat in the state government, advising the Chief Minister on all policy matters. These guys are seasoned veterans.

unnormalised: At the central government level, you’ll often hear about "Joint Secretaries," "Additional Secretaries," and "Secretaries." These are all senior bureaucrats responsible for managing different departments within the government. They assist the ministers in policy formulation and implementation. Basically, they make sure the government keeps running.
normalised: At the central government level, you will often hear about "Joint Secretaries," "Additional Secretaries," and "Secretaries." These are all senior bureaucrats responsible for managing different departments within the government. They assist the ministers in policy formulation and implementation. Basically, they make sure the government keeps running.

unnormalised: And let’s not forget the "Sarpanch" at the village level. They’re the elected head of the village panchayat, responsible for local governance and development. Even at a smaller level, these people play an important role in helping the villagers.
normalised: And let us not forget the "Sarpanch" at the village level. They are the elected head of the village panchayat, responsible for local governance and development. Even at a smaller level, these people play an important role in helping the villagers.

unnormalised: Sometimes people also refer to government officers as "Gazetted officers." This refers to officers who have the authority to issue official government orders and attest documents. There are different grades of Gazetted officers – Class I, Class II, etc. – based on their seniority and responsibilities.
normalised: Sometimes people also refer to government officers as "Gazetted officers." This refers to officers who have the authority to issue official government orders and attest documents. There are different grades of Gazetted officers – Class one, Class two, etc. – based on their seniority and responsibilities.
